column4: This will increase the airflow through the floor voids, reduce the humidity and the moisture content of linked timbers, which will greatly reduce the chances of attack by wood rotting fungi such as dry rot (serpulae lacrymans) in the future.
Lifting the airbricks will help to prevent water ponding and snow melting, causing water to run into the sub floor void, elevating the moisture levels of the timbers within.
Timbers equal to or above 20% W/W are classed as being 'at risk'.

We propose that these timbers are treated with an anti fungal fogging application. This is a short term precaution (non-guaranteed) to protect the timbers from attack whilst the improved airflow dries them out.
An inspection of timbers adjacent to damp masonry did not reveal any timber defects at the time of inspection.
An inspection of the floor timbers adjacent to the damp masonry, revealed issues with wood rot, please see attached timber inspection report for details.

column4: The timbers were suffering from the following issues:

column5: A woodworm infestation, the attack was of common furniture beetle (anobium punctatum)
An attack of wood rotting fungi, this was identified as wet rot
Rotting timbers were also suffering from an infestation of woodboring weevil (Pentarthrum Huttoni)
An attack of wood rotting fungi, this was identified as dry rot (sepulae lacrymans)
A high W/W moisture level to the floor timbers, this was due to a lack of ventilation to the sub floor voids

column4: Our surveyor has carried out an inspection of the solid walls as requested. The inspection was carried out with the aid of an electronic moisture meter, a digital laser thermometer and a tactile examination. A series of temperature, capacitive and resistive readings were obtained from interior surfaces of the wall(s), our surveyor has interpreted these results and has concluded that there is evidence of dampness to the walls of the property.

Our surveyor has carried out an inspection of the solid walls as requested. The inspection was carried out with the aid of an electronic moisture meter, a digital laser thermometer and a tactile examination. A series of temperature, capacitive and resistive readings were obtained from interior surfaces of the wall(s), our surveyor has interpreted these results and has concluded that there is evidence of condensation to the walls of the property.

Our surveyor has carried out an inspection of the solid walls as requested. The inspection was carried out with the aid of an electronic moisture meter, a digital laser thermometer and a tactile examination. A series of temperature, capacitive and resistive readings were obtained from interior surfaces of the wall(s), our surveyor has interpreted these results and has concluded that there is evidence of dampness and condensation to the walls of the property.

Our surveyor has carried out an inspection for dampness to the solid walls as requested. The inspection was carried out with the aid of an electronic moisture meter, a digital laser thermometer and a tactile examination. A series of temperature, capacitive and resistive readings were obtained from interior surfaces of the wall(s), our surveyor has interpreted these results and has concluded that there is no evidence of dampness or condensation to the walls of the property

column4: Note: This is a non-destructive inspection. You may wish to accept this report as is or you may wish to arrange for further inspection and checks, should this be the case the options available are outlined below.

Whilst this is arranged as a non-destructive inspection, properties with dampness often have problems with timbers in contact with damp masonry (such as wet rot or dry rot) leaving them at risk. If dampness is discovered, we will try to inspect any timbers in these areas of risk. This is not always possible, due to the damage that may be caused to flooring etc. We therefore cannot proceed without written permission from the property owner for a 'destructive inspection' allowing us to gain access to the sub floor voids.
We have attached a pre-filled email template to request permission for a destructive inspection, to create further access as required to complete the report.

Should you not be able to obtain permission for a destructive inspection, you may wish to negotiate  a discount to the purchase price to allow for the fact there may be treatments, or even timber replacements required.

Should you not be able to obtain permission for a destructive inspection, once you own the property, we can arrange for technicians to create access points (this will be quoted for separately, in addition to the survey cost), then arrange for our timber surveyor to return (a further inspection fee may apply). Our surveyor will then take moisture readings/carry out an inspection of exposed areas of the floor timbers. Should any further remedial work be required, a separate tender will be produced and forwarded for your consideration. Should our tender not be successful we would still highly recommend you arrange for an alternative inspection of the floor timbers under separate contract and costs.
Solid floors are not included in our inspection.
